Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks rubbish, big gaps in coverage. In some parts of this survey, image overlap was lower than that specified in the protocol. This only appears to have caused a problem in one instance, P21 (Artemisia tridentata), where the point cloud reconstruction was incomplete causing an implausible low canopy height. Because the protocol was not followed, this outlier was excluded from subsequent analysis. (by excluding this point cloud in those to be analysed for HAG)

Investigators: Fleur Visser
SiteName: Lakeside Campus, University of Worcester
CommunityDesciption: The site was sown at some unknown point in the relatively recent past, using a pasture-mixture. It therefore isnt really possible to exactly define the plant community, but by using the British National Vegetation Classification (NVC) it would be pretty close to the MG6-community. The MG6 is a mesotrophic grassland community which is a well-drained permanent pasture or meadow. In this community there are 6 constant species (species always found), in our plot we have 4 of these 6 species (Festuca rubra, Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne, Trifolium repens but not Cerastium fontanum or Cynosurus cristatus), also note here that 3 of the 4 constant species we have are the most abundant of all our species (not Holcus lanatus because we only had a few individuals).
CommunitySpecies:
Major species present:
*Festuca rubra
*Lolium perenne
*Poa annua
*Medicago lupulina
*Trifolium repens
Not major cover, but much higher than surrounding veg:
*Rumex obtusifolius
More detailed species list can be provided if needed
Phenology:
Festuca rubra - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Lolium perenne - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Poa annua - finished flowering
Medicago lupulina - flowering (slightly declining)
Trifolium repens - flowering
Rumex obtusifolius - seeds fully ripe
Soil:
Don't know exact type or depth for now, but...
According to Edina Geology:
Loam texture, firm strength, <10% CaCO3..
UKSO: Slightly acid loamy soil
Disturbance: Cropland converted to pasture (ca. 10 years ago?). Circular plot not cut this spring/summer. Surrounding grass is cut on a regular basis with a mower. No cattle present.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: 12 plots were taken within the un-cut grassland circle. 4 plots were taken outside the circle from the recently mowed surrounding grassland. In this community there are 6 constant species (species always found), in our plot we have 4 of these 6 species (Festuca rubra, Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne, Trifolium repens but not Cerastium fontanum or Cynosurus cristatus), also note here that 3 of the 4 constant species we have are the most abundant of all our species (not Holcus lanatus because we only had a few individuals).
CommunitySpecies:
Major species present:
*Festuca rubra
*Lolium perenne
*Poa annua
*Medicago lupulina
*Trifolium repens
Not major cover, but much higher than surrounding veg:
*Rumex obtusifolius
More detailed species list can be provided if needed
Phenology:
Festuca rubra - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Lolium perenne - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Poa annua - finished flowering
Medicago lupulina - flowering (slightly declining)
Trifolium repens - flowering
Rumex obtusifolius - seeds fully ripe
Additional_species_in_plot: Recently cut so difficult to say (Festuca rubra, Lolium perenne, Poa annua, Medicago lupulina, Trifolium repens, Rumex obtusifolius)
Soil:
Don't know exact type or depth for now, but...
According to Edina Geology:
Loam texture, firm strength, <10% CaCO3..
UKSO: Slightly acid loamy soil
Disturbance: Cropland converted to pasture (ca. 10 years ago?). Circular plot not cut this spring/summer. Surrounding grass is cut on a regular basis with a mower. No cattle present.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: 12 plots were taken within the un-cut grassland circle. 4 plots were taken outside the circle from the recently mowed surrounding grassland. The weather had been quite warm/sunny/dry leading up to the date of harvesting, so the grass looked very dry and some of the weeds seemed almost burnt (e.g. clover flowers). Most likely due to heavy winds earlier some of the grass was lying a bit flat (got lodged). Climate observations were from the Pershore weather station. Wind speed between 0-2 ms-1.
Acknowledgements: University of Worcester. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks good, Corner coordinates look good.

Investigators: Jason W. Karl
SiteName: Billy Creek Site #1, Craig Mountain Wildlife Management Area, Idaho
CommunityDesciption: Hells Canyon grassland. Perennial grass restoration site with some invasive annual plants
CommunitySpecies: Pseudoroegnaria spicata, Ventanata dubia, Bromus tectorum, Helianthella uniflora, Amsinckia spp., Conyza canadensis
Phenology: Pseudoroegneria spicata has set seed, but is still green. Ventenata, Bromus, and Amsinckia were fully scenesced. Helianthella and and Conyza were in full flower.
Soil: USDA Soil Series: Limekiln very gravelly silt loam to 60cm. Quick field verification, but no soil pit dug.
Disturbance: Historically used as pasture and for hay production. No livestock grazing for at least 25 years. Approx. 10 years ago herbicide treated for annual invasives and restoration seeding of bluebunch wheatgrass.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Plots harvested over Pseudoroegneria spicata only
Acknowledgements: Access to the site was provided by Idaho Department of Fish and Game
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Acknowledgements_Permission: Idaho Department of Fish and Game
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Phenology: Pseudoroegneria spicata has set seed, but is still green. Ventenata, Bromus, and Amsinckia were fully scenesced. Helianthella and and Conyza were in full flower.
Soil: USDA Soil Series: Limekiln very gravelly silt loam to 60cm. Quick field verification, but no soil pit dug.
Disturbance: Historically used as pasture and for hay production. No livestock grazing for at least 25 years. Approx. 10 years ago herbicide treated for annual invasives and restoration seeding of bluebunch wheatgrass.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Plots harvested over Pseudoroegneria spicata only.
Acknowledgements: Access to the site was provided by Idaho Department of Fish and Game

Investigators: Fleur Visser
SiteName: Hartlebury Common, Worcestershire
CommunityDesciption: Acid grassland/heath mosaic community interspersed with western gorse and locally-frequent patches of bracken. Some mixed scrub, largely made up of broom, birch saplings, bramble. So most likely British National Vegetation Classification (NVC) class H8
CommunitySpecies: Pteridium aquilinum, Calluna Vulagris, Ulex Gallii U. europaeus, Cytisus scoparius, Rubus fruticosus, Betula spp. - saplings, Festuca ovina, Erica cinerea, Agrostis capillaris, Hypnum cupressiforme, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus
Phenology: Pteridium aquilinum - ?, Calluna Vulagris - flowering, Ulex Gallii  flowering, U. europaeus - flowering, Cytisus scoparius - flowering, Rubus fruticosus - flowering, Betula spp. - saplings, Festuca ovina  Seeds, Erica cinerea  flowering, Agrostis capillaris - ?, Hypnum cupressiforme (?) - ?, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus - ?
Soil: Not observed on site, but According to Edina Geology: Loam, loose strength, no CaCO3 classification, but probably low. UKSO: Sand to Sandy Loam Arenosol
Disturbance: Current management: Restoration management to heathland in the form of scrub control primarily targeting the denser stands of mixed scrub. As well as this, the removal of saplings and many of the standard trees is also undertaken. Repeat follow up clearance and treatment will be required in subsequent years to supplement grazing.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: (Met Data from MetOffice Pershore weather station). Wind speed between 0-2 m s-1.
Acknowledgements: Worcester County Council and Natural England for allowing access to Hartlebury Common and in particular Martin Barnett for help with gorse harvesting. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Cloud_conditions: 5 - Cumulus over most of sky (sun not obscured)
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

Phenology: Pteridium aquilinum - ?, Calluna Vulagris - flowering, Ulex Gallii  flowering, U. europaeus - flowering, Cytisus scoparius - flowering, Rubus fruticosus - flowering, Betula spp. - saplings, Festuca ovina  Seeds, Erica cinerea  flowering, Agrostis capillaris - ?, Hypnum cupressiforme (?) - ?, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus - ?
Soil: Not observed on site, but According to Edina Geology: Loam, loose strength, no CaCO3 classification, but probably low. UKSO: Sand to Sandy Loam Arenosol
Disturbance: Current management: Restoration management to heathland in the form of scrub control primarily targeting the denser stands of mixed scrub. As well as this, the removal of saplings and many of the standard trees is also undertaken. Repeat follow up clearance and treatment will be required in subsequent years to supplement grazing.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: (Met Data from MetOffice Pershore weather station). Wind speed between 0-2 m s-1.
Acknowledgements: Worcester County Council and Natural England for allowing access to Hartlebury Common and in particular Martin Barnett for help with gorse harvesting. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Richard Brazier, Karen Anderson, Fabio Boschetti
SiteName: Harvest site at Willard Juniper Savannah (US-WJS), New Mexico
CommunitySpecies: Juniperus Monosperma, Bouteloa Eripoda
Phenology: Survey and harvest was carried out at the beginning of October, roughly one month after the monsoon season. The trees were close to seasonal peak biomass condition. Weather was turning cold with the beginning of Autumn.
Soil: Inceptisol (well drained with <25% clay content). Based on USA Soil Survey Maps.
Disturbance: Occasional grazing from cows.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Cunliffe et al in prep
Acknowledgements: We received permission from the landowner (Leroy Humpfries), and from the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to conduct drone operations. We are grateful to the technical staff of Sevilleta and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the measurement campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, but corner coordinates are all ca 5 cm low (within expected error, but will bias analysis).

Soil: Inceptisol (well drained with <25% clay content). Based on USA Soil Survey Maps.
Disturbance: Occasional grazing from cows.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Cunliffe et al in prep
Acknowledgements: We received permission from the landowner (Leroy Humpfries), and from the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to conduct drone operations. We are grateful to the technical staff of Sevilleta and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the measurement campaign.

Investigators: Simon Power, Michael Cramer, Julian Smit
SiteName: Protea Farm
CommunityDesciption: Montagu Shale Fynbos. Sclerophyllous shrub dominated with a few succulents.
CommunitySpecies: Dominant species: Elytropappus rhinocerotis. Species known to occur in vegetation type: Protea nitida, Protea laurifolia, Protea neriifolia, Protea repens, Dodonaea viscosa var. angustifolia, Lebeckia cytisoides, Leucadendron rubrum, Athrixia heterophylla subsp. heterophylla, Cliffortia ramosissima, Leucadendron salignum, Leucadendron salignum, Leucadendron teretifolium, Leucospermum calligerum, Protea humifloraProtea lorifolia, Protea scolopendriifolia, Protea sulphurea, Senecio pinifolius, Ursinia heterodonta, Vexatorella obtusata subsp. obtusata, Geissorhiza ornithogaloides subsp. marlothii, Ixia leipoldtii, Romulea sphaerocarpa, Wurmbea compacta, Ehrharta calycina, Ehrharta capensis, Ischyrolepis capensis, Karroochloa purpurea, Tribolium hispidum, Ixia gloriosa, Amphithalea pageae, Aspalathus rostrata, Lotononis argentea, Stirtonanthus insignis
Phenology: Full leaf out following spring.
Soil: Hard, clay, shale-derived soils
Disturbance: No known fire in > 10 years, although surrounding area burnt 1 year prior.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: "Harvest completed by Simon, Michael and Julian in one day. 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying.  See Mucina, L. & Rutherford, M.C. (eds) (2006) The vegetation of South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. Strelitzia, 19. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria for further description of vegetation type." Wind speed Avg 3.9 m/s 64 degrees and Gust 8.6 m/s direction 76 degrees. Light breeze.
Acknowledgements: University of Cape Town research council award.
Acknowledgements_Funding: University of Cape Town
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Investigators: Chandra Holifield Collins, Philip Heilman additional Contributors: Gerardo Armendariz, Jason Wong, Andrew Corrales, Aaron Sobel, Chad Radford, Zachary Winston, Ross Bryant, Eric Spangler, Travis Whitehead, John Smith
SiteName: WGEW (Walnut Gulch Experimental Watershed)
CommunityDesciption: Shrub-dominated with some perennial grass presence
CommunitySpecies: Larrea tridentata, Parthenium incanum, Flourensia cernua, Zinnia acerosa, Muhlenbergia porteri, Hilaria belangeri, Aristida L.
Phenology: Shrubs were leafed out, but past flowering . Grasses were showing inflorescence and dried out.
Soil: Pedrogosa soil, Limy Upland ecological site
Disturbance: un-grazed for 30 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest completed in a single day, with 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying. Drying occurred in small groups due to oven size restrictions.  Only the target species was harvested from each plot. Example: C1 (only the LATR2 - creosote bush) was clipped for biomass. This time was definitely past peak of the growing season.  DJI Phantom 4 Pro v2.0.
Acknowledgements: Thank you to Kelly Young for Landowner Permission
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Gerardo Armendariz, Jason Wong, Andrew Corrales, Aaron Sobel, Chad Radford, Zachary Winston, Ross Bryant, Eric Spangler, Travis Whitehead, John Smith

Investigators: Investigators: Chandra Holifield Collins, Philip Heilman additional Contributors: Gerardo Armendariz, Jason Wong, Andrew Corrales, Aaron Sobel, Chad Radford, Zachary Winston, Ross Bryant, Eric Spangler, Travis Whitehead, John Smith
SiteName: WGEW (Walnut Gulch Experimental Watershed)
CommunityDesciption: Shrub-dominated with some perennial grass presence
CommunitySpecies: Larrea tridentata, Parthenium incanum, Flourensia cernua, Zinnia acerosa, Muhlenbergia porteri, Hilaria belangeri, Aristida L.
Phenology: Shrubs were leafed out, but past flowering . Grasses were showing inflorescence and dried out.
Soil: Pedrogosa soil, Limy Upland ecological site
Disturbance: un-grazed for 30 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest completed in a single day, with 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying. Drying occurred in small groups due to oven size restrictions.  Only the target species was harvested from each plot. Example: C1 (only the LATR2 - creosote bush) was clipped for biomass. This time was definitely past peak of the growing season.  DJI Phantom 4 Pro v2.0.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti
SiteName: Harvest plot 2 (HAR2), Sevilleta Grassland (US-SEG), New Mexico
CommunitySpecies: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at the end of February. All of the species were in dormant phase.
Soil: Turney loams overlaying a well_developed petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45_m below the surface
Disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. Very windy during survey.
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

CommunitySpecies: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at the end of February. All of the species were in dormant phase.
Soil: Turney loams overlaying a well_developed petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45_m below the surface
Disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. Very windy during survey.
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay (but with lots of messy negative points), corner coordinates are plausible.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Breahna Gillespie
SiteName: Sky Oaks Chaparral, California (analouge for SO2)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Adenostoma fasciculatum, Adenostoma sparsifolium, Ceanothus Perplexans
Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
Soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
Disturbance: Wildfire in 2003 ('Cyote fire'). Age before wildfire: 80 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 2 days: 18th and 19th March 2019. references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet
Acknowledgements: We received permission from SDSU Research Foundation and from the site's PI (Walter Oechel) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to Richard Brazier, Walter Oechel and the SDSU Global Change Research Group for their support during the field campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud is a bit sparse over the plant. Corners are ca. 3 cm high.

KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Adenostoma fasciculatum, Adenostoma sparsifolium, Ceanothus Perplexans
Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
Soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
Disturbance: Wildfire in 2003 ('Cyote fire'). Age before wildfire: 80 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 2 days: 18th and 19th March 2019. references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet
Acknowledgements: We received permission from SDSU Research Foundation and from the site's PI (Walter Oechel) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to Richard Brazier, Walter Oechel and the SDSU Global Change Research Group for their support during the field campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks ok. Corners are ok.

SiteName: Sky Oaks Chaparral, California (analouge for SO2)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Adenostoma fasciculatum, Adenostoma sparsifolium, Ceanothus Perplexans
Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
Soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
Disturbance: Wildfire in 2003 ('Cyote fire'). Age before wildfire: 80 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 2 days: 18th and 19th March 2019. references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet
Acknowledgements: We received permission from SDSU Research Foundation and from the site's PI (Walter Oechel) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to Richard Brazier, Walter Oechel and the SDSU Global Change Research Group for their support during the field campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
Soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
Disturbance: Last wildfire is estimated to have occurred around 1918
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 3 days: March 30th, 31st and April 13th 2019 references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet
Acknowledgements: We received permission from SDSU Research Foundation and from the site's PI (Walter Oechel) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to Richard Brazier, Walter Oechel and the SDSU Global Change Research Group for their support during the field campaign.

Investigators: Patrick E. Clark
SiteName: RCEW-WBS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - Wyoming big sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Tetradymia canescens, Chrysothamnus viscidiflorus, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Elymus elymoides, Poa secunda, Bromus tectorum, Phlox longifolia, Astragalus cusickii, Antennaria dimorpha, Crepis acuminata, Zigadenus paniculatus
Phenology: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis =just past peak greenness, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata = soft dough, Elymus elymoides = soft dough, Poa secunda = hard seed
Additional_species_in_plot: ARTRW8, PHLO2, ELEL5, POSE, PHLO2, PSSP6,CHVI8
Soil: Glasgow loam, 0-30% slope, Fine, smectitic, mesic Xeric Haplargids ('Glasgow soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
Disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion as a consequence of localized, pocket gopher disturbance. Last wildfire was likely in the mid-1930s.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016). NB. Convergent images were taken at a 65 degree angle rather than the 25 degrees target angle.
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

CommunitySpecies: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Tetradymia canescens, Chrysothamnus viscidiflorus, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Elymus elymoides, Poa secunda, Bromus tectorum, Phlox longifolia, Astragalus cusickii, Antennaria dimorpha, Crepis acuminata, Zigadenus paniculatus
Phenology: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis =just past peak greenness, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata = soft dough, Elymus elymoides = soft dough, Poa secunda = hard seed
Additional_species_in_plot: ARTRW8, PHLO2. POSE, PSSP6, ASCU5, ANDI2
Soil: Glasgow loam, 0-30% slope, Fine, smectitic, mesic Xeric Haplargids ('Glasgow soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
Disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion as a consequence of localized, pocket gopher disturbance. Last wildfire was likely in the mid-1930s.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016). NB. Convergent images were taken at a 65 degree angle rather than the 25 degrees target angle.
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Jason W. Karl
SiteName: USA-ID_RockCreek_GlendaleRoad
CommunityDesciption: Low-sage (Artemisia arbuscula ssp. longiloba) overstory with Sandberg's bluegrass (Poa pratensis) understory
CommunitySpecies: Artemisia arbuscula ssp longiloba, Poa pratensis, Bromus tectorum, Elymus elymoides
Phenology: sagebrush in full leaf but post flowering (longiloba is a spring-flowering sagebrush), grasses in full seedhead
Additional_species_in_plot: Herbaceous species (Poa secunda and Bromus arvensis)
Soil: Peeveywell soil component: clay loam soils; depth to durapan ~ 0.75-1.0m
Disturbance: Cattle grazing annually. Most recently 2-month prior to sampling
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NA
Acknowledgements: Rinker Rock Creek Ranch is a research unit of the University of Idaho. Flight permission granted by the University of Idaho UAS Committee. Funding provided by USDA MacIntire-Stennis award to the College of Natural Resources, University of Idaho.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA MacIntire-Stennis award
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Patrick E. Clark
SiteName: RCEW-LOS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - low sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Artemisia arbuscula, Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Festuca idahoensis, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Poa secunda, Elymus elymoides, Bromus tectorum, Lupinus argenteus, Phlox longifolia, Astragulus cuskii, Epilobium minutum, Eriogonum microthecum
Phenology: Artemisia arbuscula = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough
Soil: Searla gravelly loam, 0-30% slope, Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Calcic Argixerolls ('Searla soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
Disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion. Last wildfire was at least prior to mid-1930s
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016)
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

CommunitySpecies: Artemisia arbuscula, Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Festuca idahoensis, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Poa secunda, Elymus elymoides, Bromus tectorum, Lupinus argenteus, Phlox longifolia, Astragulus cuskii, Epilobium minutum, Eriogonum microthecum
Phenology: Artemisia arbuscula = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough
Soil: Searla gravelly loam, 0-30% slope, Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Calcic Argixerolls ('Searla soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
Disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion. Last wildfire was at least prior to mid-1930s
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016)
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti
SiteName: Harvest plot 2 (HAR2), Sevilleta Grassland (US-SEG), New Mexico
CommunitySpecies: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
Phenology: Unknown
Soil: Turney loams overlaying a well_developed petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45_m below the surface
Disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest conducted in one morning, between 0730 and 1030. This harvest follows a very wet winter/spring in this water limited ecosystem.
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Patrick E. Clark
SiteName: Nancy's Gulch, RCEW-MBS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - mountain big sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
CommunitySpecies: Artemisia tridentata vaseyana, Symphoricarpos oreophilus utahensis, Bromus marginatus, Poa pratensis, Elymus elymoides, Lupinus argenteus, Eriogonum heracleoides, Achillea millefolium, Crepis acuminata, Polygonum douglasii
Phenology: Artemisia tridentata vaseyana = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough
Soil: Gabica cobbly gravelly loam, 0-30% slope, Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Lithic Argixerolls ('Gabica soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
Disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Last wildfire unknown but probably prior to mid-1930s
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016).
Notes_on_plot: NB. This plots was outside of both nadir and convergent drone surveys.
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Sergio A.Vargas Z (S.A.Vargas Z); Craig Tweedie (C.E. Tweedie)
SiteName: Utqiagvik (formerly Barrow), Alaska
CommunityDesciption: Mixed vascular and non-vascular composition (Bryophytes, Deciduous shrubs, Forbs, Graminoids, Lichens), ranging from dry-dwarf shrub-graminoid tundra to wet graminoid tundra
CommunitySpecies: Arctophila fulva, Carex aquatilis and other
Phenology: peak phenological stage for both Arctophila and Carex
Soil: Continuous permafrost, from dry heath to wet meadow
Disturbance: undisturbed tundra landscape
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. INPUT IMAGE QUALITY IS POOR. The site is situated on the edge of and within a dry lake basin consisting mostly of wet graminoid tundra. Peak season is characterized by moist to wet soil conditions with standing surface water in most cases, an ideal state for Arctophila. The tendency for this species to mostly thrive alone made it a target taxa for this study as this landscape is typically composed of a mixture of species within a small area making up the complex landscape plant communities. Vegetation was a mixture between 10 and 11 on the IGBP classes. Biomass dried at ca. 60 degrees C. There was some surface water in most plots. The first flight started at 11:52 am local AK (19:52 UTC) and the last flight ended at 12:35 pm local AK (20:35 UTC).
Acknowledgements: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA, Julio Ceniceros, Mariana Orejel
Acknowledgements_Funding: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

CommunityDesciption: Mixed vascular and non-vascular composition (Bryophytes, Deciduous shrubs, Forbs, Graminoids, Lichens), ranging from dry-dwarf shrub-graminoid tundra to wet graminoid tundra
CommunitySpecies: Arctophila fulva, Carex aquatilis and other
Phenology: peak phenological stage for both Arctophila and Carex
Soil: Continuous permafrost, from dry heath to wet meadow
Disturbance: undisturbed tundra landscape
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. INPUT IMAGE QUALITY IS POOR. The site is situated on the edge of and within a dry lake basin consisting mostly of wet graminoid tundra. Peak season is characterized by moist to wet soil conditions with standing surface water in most cases, an ideal state for Arctophila. The tendency for this species to mostly thrive alone made it a target taxa for this study as this landscape is typically composed of a mixture of species within a small area making up the complex landscape plant communities. Vegetation was a mixture between 10 and 11 on the IGBP classes. Biomass dried at ca. 60 degrees C. There was some surface water in most plots. The first flight started at 11:52 am local AK (19:52 UTC) and the last flight ended at 12:35 pm local AK (20:35 UTC).
Acknowledgements: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA, Julio Ceniceros, Mariana Orejel
Acknowledgements_Funding: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 2
CommunityDesciption: Grassland with assorted species, dominated by thistles
CommunitySpecies: Cirsium spinosissimum, graminoids
Phenology: thistles full-grown and in full bloom, all other flowers in full bloom, grasses with maximum height
Soil: raw soil, Regosol
Disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 120 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1850 and 1922).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be seperated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values).
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).
Acknowledgements_Funding: EU Horizon 2020 grant No. 776681 (PHUSICOS)
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Barbara Pachler, Ulrich Zangerl, Gerald Griesebner
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 3
CommunityDesciption: Grassland with assorted species, dominated by thistles
CommunitySpecies: Cirsium spinosissimum, graminoids
Phenology: thistles full-grown and in full bloom, all other flowers in full bloom, grasses with maximum height
Soil: raw soil, Regosol
Disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 120 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1850 and 1922).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be seperated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values).

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 2
CommunityDesciption: Partially covered with moss and small grasses, dominating plant is the thistle
CommunitySpecies: Cirsium spinosissimum, Bryophyta
Phenology: full-grown and in full bloom
Soil: raw soil
Disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 70 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1922 and 1971).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Review of UAV images (by Andy) suggests that many images are also quite dark (underexposed). Ii appears that camera settings were fixed despite variable illumination conditions. Camera angles appear sub-optimal, esp. on non-nadir images; this might have been very steep ground? NB. Only 12 GCPs were geolocated. Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be separated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values), ca. 15 km distant.
Notes_on_plot: This sample started decomposing before being dried in the lab, so the AGB provides only a minimum estimate of the AGB.
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).
Acknowledgements_Funding: EU Horizon 2020 grant No. 776681 (PHUSICOS)
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Barbara Pachler, Ulrich Zangerl, Gerald Griesebner
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Soil: raw soil
Disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 70 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1922 and 1971).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Review of UAV images (by Andy) suggests that many images are also quite dark (underexposed). Ii appears that camera settings were fixed despite variable illumination conditions. Camera angles appear sub-optimal, esp. on non-nadir images; this might have been very steep ground? NB. Only 12 GCPs were geolocated. Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be separated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values), ca. 15 km distant.
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).

Investigators: Ji_ Pro_ek; Kate_ina Gdulov; Petra _mov
SiteName: Doupovsk hory (Rado_ov)
CommunityDesciption: shrubland consisting of a mosaic of herbaceous and shrub vegetation
CommunitySpecies: Shrubs (Crataegus sp., Prunus spinosa, Rosa canina), Acidophilous dry meandows (Achillea millefolium, Agrimonia eupatoria, Galium sp., Alchemilla vulgaris, Fragaria sp.)
Phenology: Late biomass peak (fully developed leaves/foliage; without ripe fruits)
Soil: Cambisols and Podzols (according to a national database)
Disturbance: Non-known (limited long-term information, but there wasnt any evidently disturbance in last decade. This area is accessible to wild animals, which can browse on the shrubs but that was not abundantly evident (habit (shape) of the shrubs was natural, unaffected; not like a bonsai). The current form of the locality is result of natural succession).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Locality already used in study: Pro_ek, J., & _mov, P. (2019). UAV for mapping shrubland vegetation: Does fusion of spectral and vertical information derived from a single sensor increase the classification accuracy? International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation, 75, 151-162. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2018.10.009. Roles: Ji_ Pro_ek: Organization and preparing of our part of the experiment (including the laboratory/drying procedure), performing of the UAV flight, field work and harvesting. Petra _mov: Managing and funding agreement of our part of the experiment, ensure permission and consulting with respect to expertise knowledge of locality Kate_ina Gdulov: RTK GNSS survey (harvested plots, UAV ground control markers) and GNSS data processing, field work and harvesting, botanic expertise). Note that sampled individuals all appear fairly small, and so might not be representative of the full size range these species can cover. First survey/flight was performed between 11:00  11:20 UTC (nadir camera orientation) and second survey/flight was performed during 11:28  11:48 UTC (25/75 camera orientation).
Acknowledgements: Funding by Department of Applied Geoinformatics and Spatial Planning and Spatial Science in Ecology and Environment group (Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Praha  Suchdol, Czech Republic)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Czech University of Life Sciences, Prague
Acknowledgements_Permission: Nature Conservation Agency of the Czech Republic
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

CommunitySpecies: Shrubs (Crataegus sp., Prunus spinosa, Rosa canina), Acidophilous dry meandows (Achillea millefolium, Agrimonia eupatoria, Galium sp., Alchemilla vulgaris, Fragaria sp.)
Phenology: Late biomass peak (fully developed leaves/foliage; without ripe fruits)
Soil: Cambisols and Podzols (according to a national database rather than field observations)
Disturbance: Non-known (limited long-term information, but there wasnt any evidently disturbance in last decade. This area is accessible to wild animals, which can browse on the shrubs but that was not abundantly evident (habit (shape) of the shrubs was natural, unaffected; not like a bonsai). The current form of the locality is result of natural succession).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Locality already used in study: Pro_ek, J., & _mov, P. (2019). UAV for mapping shrubland vegetation: Does fusion of spectral and vertical information derived from a single sensor increase the classification accuracy? International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation, 75, 151-162. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2018.10.009. Roles: Ji_ Pro_ek: Organization and preparing of our part of the experiment (including the laboratory/drying procedure), performing of the UAV flight, field work and harvesting. Petra _mov: Managing and funding agreement of our part of the experiment, ensure permission and consulting with respect to expertise knowledge of locality Kate_ina Gdulov: RTK GNSS survey (harvested plots, UAV ground control markers) and GNSS data processing, field work and harvesting, botanic expertise). Note that sampled individuals all appear fairly small, and so might not be representative of the full size range these species can cover. First survey/flight was performed between 11:00  11:20 UTC (nadir camera orientation) and second survey/flight was performed during 11:28  11:48 UTC (25/75 camera orientation).
Acknowledgements: Funding by Department of Applied Geoinformatics and Spatial Planning and Spatial Science in Ecology and Environment group (Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Praha  Suchdol, Czech Republic)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Czech University of Life Sciences, Prague
Acknowledgements_Permission: Nature Conservation Agency of the Czech Republic
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti
SiteName: SEG Harvest Area 3, Sevilleta LTER, New Mexico
CommunitySpecies: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
Phenology: TBC
Soil: Turney loams overlaying a well_developed petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45_m below the surface
Disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: This harvest follows an extreemly dry summer (one of the dryiest on record).
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to REB, AMC, KA, SS.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti, Sergio Vargas, Stephen Escarzaga, Craig Tweedie, Wenjie Ji, Robert Wojcikiewicz, Niall Hanon, Caiti Steele, Muhammad S. Hanggito, Marguerite E. Mauritz-Tozer
SiteName: Site C (C-SAND, Jornada LTER, New Mexico)
CommunityDesciption: Creosote-dominated bajada, with some herbacious plants (grasses and forbs) and some cacti.
CommunitySpecies: Larrea tridentata, some Cylindropuntia imbricata
Phenology: Leaves  on, no inflorescence.
Soil: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, thermic Ustic Haplocalcid
Disturbance: No known disturbance. C-SAND site located on NMSU Chihuahuan Desert Research Center has been excluded from domestic grazing since at least the 1970's.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Andrew Cunliffe.
Acknowledgements: funding Jornada LTER (NSF 1235828). Permission Jornada LTER and ARS (Study number 545). Assistance John Anderson, Qiuyan Yu, Julius Anchang, C. Wade Ross, Danielle Lara, Niall Hanan, Lara Prihodk PLUS TBC folks from NMSU.

SiteName: Site M (M-RABB, Jornada LTER, New Mexico)
CommunityDesciption: Mesquite dunefield, relativly low stature mesquite.
CommunitySpecies: Prosopis glandulosa, Atriplex canescens
Phenology: Seasional peak biomass, following some large precipitation evens a few weeks previously.
Soil: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, thermic Ustic Petroargids
Disturbance: No known disturbance. Site was located on USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range. Grazing history is light to moderate domestic grazing historically. It has been light grazing since at least the 1970's. There is rotational grazing among fenced pastures, timing dependent on quantity and quality of forage. Cattle numbers on the range are reduced during drought and grass-stressed years.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Caiti Steele and Robert Wojcikiewicz.
Acknowledgements: funding Jornada LTER (NSF 1235828). Permission Jornada LTER and ARS (Study number 545). Assistance John Anderson, Qiuyan Yu, Julius Anchang, C. Wade Ross, Danielle Lara, Niall Hanan, Lara Prihodk PLUS TBC folks from NMSU.

SiteName: Site 1 - One Tree Hill (private land), Bredbo, NSW
CommunityDesciption: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
CommunitySpecies: Bothriochloa macra, Eragrostis curvula, Nassella trichotoma + 5-10 minor grass species + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
Phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
Soil: shallow (<40 cm), rapidly drained Lithosols (Uc1.43, Um1.43), well-drained Red Earths (Gn2.12, Gn2.15, K-Gn2.12, K-Gn2.15) and moderately well-drained Non-calcic Brown Soils (Dr2.12) and Red Podzolic Soils (Dr2.52) on crests and upper slopes.
Disturbance: Up to ~1980 was part of sheep grazing station, but generally lightly grazed due to location and distance to water source. Tree recruitment was still was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). No evidence of recent fire
Notes_on_survey_harvest: hill top site - very exposed, gets several snow falls each. year. Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

SiteName: Site 2 - Cottage Flat (private land), Bredbo, NSW
CommunityDesciption: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
CommunitySpecies: Eragrostis curvula, Bothriochloa macra + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
Phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
Soil: Moderately well-drained Yellow Earths (Gn2.42, Gn2.22) and Red Earths (Gn2.21) on lower slopes. Shallow <30-40cm
Disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally shallow soil site with rocky outcrops.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Soil: Moderately well-drained Yellow Earths (Gn2.42, Gn2.22) and Red Earths (Gn2.21) on lower slopes. Shallow <30-40cm
Disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally shallow soil site with rocky outcrops.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

SiteName: Site 3 - River End (private land), Bredbo, NSW
CommunityDesciption: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
CommunitySpecies: Juncus (mostly J. alexandri), Eragrostis curvula + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
Phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
Soil: Moderately well-drained to imperfectly drained Alluvial Soils (NSG) of variable depth (10-100cm)
Disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally wet site on river alluvial plain, gets fairly consistent seepage from uphill slopes.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

Investigators: Simon Jones, Bryan Hally, James McGlade, Samuel Hillman
SiteName: High Camp
CommunitySpecies: Cassinia arcuata (Asteraceae),  Austrodanthonia eriantha, Austrodanthonia geniculata, Austrodanthonia sp.1, Austrostipa scabra, Austrostipa sp., Joycea pallida, Microlaena stipoides, (all Poaceae)
Phenology: spring, (already very dry) full leaf
Soil: Shallow metamorphosed sedimentary rocks
Disturbance: Site has been disturbed by low level grazing, farm animals excluded for 10+ years, still Kangaroo grazing at high level.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NA
Acknowledgements: Bushfire and Natural Hazard CRC, permission granted
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
